Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Modular Biodiesel Production with Glycerol Recycle
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project can transform the waste vegetable oil industry and influence the markets of other biofuels. The innovative method comes from using a modular design with novel supercritical processing technology that utilizes value added by-product recycle. This technology improves profitability by bringing processing facilities closer to the consumer and creating local jobs in rural communities, thus improving rural economic activity. The commercial potential of this technology can transform how waste vegetable oil is used, rendered, and processed in the United States and around the world. These marketplaces are of significant interest to the federal and state governments because of energy security, rural economic growth and sustainable energy production. Commercial impacts of this technology influence other biofuels markets.

This I-Corps project will explore the market potential of a Transportable Micro Bio Refinery (TmBR) that converts waste vegetable oil (WVO) into biodiesel to using a novel 2-stage Separative-reactor. Generating biodiesel from WVO is commonly done using a Base-Catalyzed Low-Pressure process referred to as the Fatty-Acid Methyl Ester (FAME) process. Bio-diesel produced in centralized bio-refineries are not competitive with petro-diesel with low priced crude. Capital costs, feedstock supply costs, and environmental costs to dispose of process waste make centralized refineries uneconomically. By comparison, the TmBR process uses an advanced super-critical separative reactor without a catalyst to reduce process waste and operating costs. In addition, the TmBR process includes a bio-digestor to convert waste glycerol to methanol which is recycled to reduce the need to purify and dispose of waste glycerol. The TmBR process requires a smaller operating footprint, involves lower capital costs and reduced operating costs and has less environmental impact that makes this technology more economically competitive compared to standard FAME based biodiesel plants.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome:

  • Our I-Corps team consisted of a principle investigator (PI) and entrepreneurial lead (EL) from Missouri University of Science & Technology (MS&T), with a business mentor from Baylor University.
  • Our team participated in the 7-week intensive I-Corps workshop which began and ended with on-sight meetings in Denver, Colorado.  During the workshop, we interviewed 131 individuals (115 face to face, 2 Skype, 14 phone) from different parts of the biodiesel supply chain in the USA.
  • After the I-Corps workshop, the team continued customer discovery and hypothesis testing conducting an additional 30 interviews from the biodiesel supply chain.
  • Based on feedback received during customer interviews, our team identified and implemented an key change to our technology that enables us to convert (recycle) waste glycerol formed during the biodiesel process into ethanol/methanol to improve the profitability of our process for the biodiesel industry.

Intellectual Merit:

  • Publications included a two-page I-Corps summary, two conference presentations, one poster presentation, and one PhD research project (with three technical papers).
  • The Entrepreneurial lead was invited to join the Next Generation Scientist for Biodiesel (NGSB) program by the National Biodiesel Board (NBB). The National Biodiesel Board is the national trade association representing America's first Advanced Biofuel (biodiesel).
  • Lessons learned from the NSF I-Corps were presented at the NBB technical conference in Kansas City, MO. Participants in this conference included representatives from state, national, and international feedstock and feedstock processor organizations, biodiesel suppliers, policy makers, scientists, petroleum fuel producers, fuel marketers, and distributors, and technology providers.
  • The PI and entrepreneurial lead have developed and plan to submit a provisional patent application on our process.

Broder Impacts:

  • Student training: 5 Undergraduates and 1 PhD student
  • Our technology designed to convert waste glycerol to ethanol will help improve the biodiesel industry by increasing profit, and adding jobs to economically disadvantage rural areas in the United States.  
  • Students who participated in this program gained valuable professional experience not available in the laboratory or classroom. This experience has helped them in their professional careers (many other students expressed interest in joining the I-Corps program).
  • The experience gained from the I-Corps program has been shared at our university and local high school.
  • The PI has promoted entrepreneurial activities across the USA by being part of other I-Corps teams as a mentor.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Project Outcome: Our I-Corps team consisted of a principle investigator (PI) and entrepreneurial lead (EL) from Missouri University of Science & Technology (MS&T), with a business mentor from Baylor University. Our team participated in the 7-week intensive I-Corps workshop which began and ended with on-sight meetings in Denver, Colorado. During the workshop, we interviewed 131 individuals (115 face to face, 2 Skype, 14 phone) from different parts of the biodiesel supply chain in the USA. After the I-Corps workshop, the team continued customer discovery and hypothesis testing conducting an additional 30 interviews from the biodiesel supply chain. Based on feedback received during customer interviews, our team identified and implemented an key change to our technology that enables us to convert (recycle) waste glycerol formed during the biodiesel process into ethanol/methanol to improve the profitability of our process for the biodiesel industry. Intellectual Merit: Publications included a two-page I-Corps summary, two conference presentations, one poster presentation, and one PhD research project (with three technical papers). The Entrepreneurial lead was invited to join the Next Generation Scientist for Biodiesel (NGSB) program by the National Biodiesel Board (NBB). The National Biodiesel Board is the national trade association representing America's first Advanced Biofuel (biodiesel). Lessons learned from the NSF I-Corps were presented at the NBB technical conference in Kansas City, MO. Participants in this conference included representatives from state, national, and international feedstock and feedstock processor organizations, biodiesel suppliers, policy makers, scientists, petroleum fuel producers, fuel marketers, and distributors, and technology providers. The PI and entrepreneurial lead have developed and plan to submit a provisional patent application on our process. Broder Impacts: Student training: 5 Undergraduates and 1 PhD student Our technology designed to convert waste glycerol to ethanol will help improve the biodiesel industry by increasing profit, and adding jobs to economically disadvantage rural areas in the United States. Students who participated in this program gained valuable professional experience not available in the laboratory or classroom. This experience has helped them in their professional careers (many other students expressed interest in joining the I-Corps program). The experience gained from the I-Corps program has been shared at our university and local high school. The PI has promoted entrepreneurial activities across the USA by being part of other I-Corps teams as a mentor. Last Modified: 04/04/2019 Submitted by: Joseph D Smith
